When Signal gets a message, there is no kind of rate limit on notifications. So, if I am in a large-ish group, my phone will buzz for every message, sometimes for hours at a time. Of course, I can then set it to mute for e.g. 2h, but most other apps have an automatic rate limiting instead. For example, the the app will only buzz x times in y minutes (telegram), or a maximum of three times per unread chat (whatsapp).

This is, IMO, a must-have feature for working in any group with more than a few people.

posts.name: Baltoche
posts.cooked:
This is a real show stopper.

I am trying to get my contacts to switch to Signal but they all complain of the very low signal to noise ratio on the notifications and end up leaving in frustration.

Whenever a group chat becomes active, the phone starts vibrating and beeping non stop. You must either mute it for a minimum of one hour or participate immediately; either way, you must interrupt your current activity and act to preserve your sanity.

baltoche:

they all complain of the very low signal to noise ratio on the notifications

As a workaround, in my signalapp groupchats I tend to create two nearly-identical groupchats, one called projectFooAlerts and the other called projectFooDiscussion.

Workaround: how to operate double-groupchats-with-one-of-them-muted

I add all 20 people to both of the groupchats, and when a new person is invited they are also always added to both groupchats as well. There is a groupchat etiquette (socially enforced not technologically enforced) that only myself or somebody I deputize is allowed to invite new people to join. Then, I appoint a “town crier” … or do the work myself if need be … who is responsible for summarizing the last 24 hours of projectFooDiscussion into a daily digest-report that is posted into projectFooAlerts. 90% of the messages will be sent and received in projectFooDiscussion, but from time to time somebody will send directly to projectFooAlerts.

To make this all work, I instruct people in the double-groupchats to go ahead and leave notifications turn ON for projectFooAlerts, which will generally give them only a small number of ding&buzz incidents per day (usually alerts they do need to read right away… or the usual daily-digest which always appears at roughly the same time-of-day). If they are busy folks, I tell them to feel free to turn notifications OFF for projectFooDiscussion, but to remain subscribed to the groupchat of course. They will not miss anything crucial, because the town-crier will post digest-summaries of all the key decisions from projectFooDiscussion into their daily blast with projectFooAlerts.

This all functions pretty well in practice. The mains downside is that people take some training before they can use the discipline NOT to reply directly in projectFooAlerts, and to remember to switch over to projectFooDiscussion when they want to discuss a recent alert-message. There is also an additional step required when signing somebody up (adding them to both groupchats), and this causes double-ding&buzz for all groupchat members, but in practice this has not been annoying because the membership is pretty stable.

In the long run, it would definitely be an improvement for me if this was supported in a more-automated-fashion. In particular, I’d like to have the option when sending any given message, as to whether it would cause the recipient’s handset to ding, buzz, vibrate, or play an emergency-klaxon-sound, as well as whether it should cause a screen-popup-notification to appear. This is similar to the email-feature where a message can have an ‘importance’ flag attached in the SMTP headers (“high priority” / “low priority” / etc), but instead of being vague and letting the recipient-app determine how to render, just specifies explicitly what I-as-the-sender think ought to happen in terms of notification-behavior.

As a recipient, of course, I want to be able to specify how incoming messages are ACTUALLY treated, on a per-sender basis (and ideally on a per-sender-per-groupchat basis). When my spouse sends me a normal textual-message with the normal notification-intent specified, I want my phone to ding&buzz with a custom dingtone. When my spouse sends me a textual-message with special do-not-ding-do-not-buzz specified on their end, I want my phone to stay silent. However, when my paranoid boss sends me a message like that, instead of my phone following instructions and staying silent, what I as the recipient want is for the klaxon-sound to start going off :-)

Fix: per-message notification-intents, and per-sender-per-groupchat notification-handlers, eliminate the need for double-groupchats and may also solve auto-mute

With those new feature-requests, I would never need to operate double-groupchats-with-one-of-them-muted. I would only need a single groupchat, which was set to vibrate-by-default-only, and the town-crier would be instructed to send their digest-summary reports with ding&buzz explicitly enabled. If one of the participants was over-using the ability to make my phone sound a klaxon by specifying that sound in their notification-intent, I would as the recipient be able to set a per-sender-per-groupchat behavior that merely vibrated in such cases.

Those feature-requests, plus a bit more added to the control-knobs, would also allow people to perform rate-limiting of their incoming notifications. In other words, once you can specify the per-sender-per-groupchat behavior you want for incoming messages, you can also pretty easily specify per-sender-per-groupchat-per-time-interval settings: I want incoming messages from Bob to always ding, even when she specifies a notification-intent of ‘klaxon’ … and in addition, whenever I receive more than 3 messages in a 1-minute timespan that I have not responded to, I want the 4th and subsequent dings to be muted, until at least an hour has passed at which point reset the ding-behavior to normal. With messages from Alice on the other hand, I want even messages she sends with no-ding no-buzz notification-intent to set off the contact-specific klaxon, and I never want to rate-limit.

See also: Add silent hours interval for notifications , Silent, low priority messages to avoid disturbing the receiver (Silent messages) , as well as the DND-related Contact-specific notification channels (including calls)

baltoche:

Whenever a group chat becomes active, the phone starts vibrating and beeping non stop. You must either mute it for a minimum of one hour or participate immediately

I am not against there being an optional feature to auto-mute … but I would not want it to be on by default. If my groupchat is active for a few seconds because somebody sent a notification and there were a couple questions about it, the brief round of buzzing (I tend to prefer that over ding&buzz) tells me that there was a short discussion. By contrast, if there is a huge problem, or a long-running discussion, if auto-mute was on by default … and especially if there was no way to turn auto-mute OFF … then from my perspective, it would still “sound like” a short discussion, because my phone would be hiding the explosion of messaging from me. In my use-case, typically a lot of messages means an emergency :-)

But even for normal endusers using signalapp to chat with friends, a lot of messages usually indicates that a chat-party is ongoing, and I might not want to miss out on the fun ;-)

baltoche:

you must interrupt your current activity and act to preserve your sanity

Necessarily my suggestion does mean that the enduser would have to take SOME action at some point, such as enabling the auto-mute feature for specific groupchats. But it would be a relatively small amount of effort to do that, methinks.

That said, different people have very different views on how to maintain sanity. For my own purposes, generally I set all messages&calls to buzz-only. I would also like the ability to send a signal-caller to voicemail, which would improve my sanity. But I do want to get one buzz per message… that is partly how I tell whether I need to pull the phone out of my pocket, by volume-of-buzzing. Allowing the sender to specify an urgency-level (i.e. specify a notification-intent that says whether they want my phone to buzz, ding, ring, klaxon, flash the LED, give a screen-popup, or do nothing beyond incrementing the message-counter) would improve my sanity further.

Having signalapp start automagically deciding which conversations to automute FOR me would be a nightmare for my sanity :-) Though I do understand how many folks would like that, I prefer it to be an optional-off-by-default feature. I also suspect that it needs to be “optional” because different people will want automuting to function in different ways i.e. with different parameters/options: some want rate-limiting after the first 30 seconds and uncapping 3 hours later, some want rate-limiting after the first 3 minutes and uncapping 30 minutes later, and so on. Some will want only certain contacts in a groupchat auto-muted, depending on whether they are ‘starred’ or whatever. It is hard to imaging a one-size-fits-all auto-mute aka rate-limiting behavior, but if the feature is to be added (even off-by-default) we need to come up with a sane one-size-fits-most default when it is turned on.

posts.cooked: I do hope this is implemented and not just for groups. 1-to-1 chats can get busy too, and it would be very welcome to rate-limit notifications on the more eager of our contacts. Ideally there should be one or two notifications and then silence until the messages have been read.

We all know how disturbing it can be when you get a bazillion messages in a short time. Sometimes even beeping multiple times in a second for each notification.

WhatsApp and/or Telegram do not notify every single message when they arrive in rapid succession. Instead they have a 5 minutes or so cool-off phase. You still get the messages, but you are not alerted each time during that cool-off phase. First of all, I would like to see the same functionality in Signal.

Further, we can expand on that idea and add a do-not-disturbe day-time filter. Lets say you only want to be notified once every hour. So your phone will beep only once per hour (if you got at least any message). Theorethically, you should be able to spend less time than answering each message individually. You just look on your phone once, and answer all that have arrived until then.

And before someonce says that this will add a delay to conversations, yes I know! But imagine it this way. Email clients used to work the same way, only connecting once every 5 min to 1 hour. And I would say the majority of messages sent and recieved are not time critical. Or if they are, you will be contacted via signal call or telephone anyway. (Also, an “unmute” button for important contacts to reach you anytime or so)

The use case would be during school or working hours. Or when you are out for a hike, in nature, etc.

Lets slow down this rapid world a little (from the receiver side).

The lack of a feature like this has brought me to the point where I now spend the Corona-lockdown days on implementing this myself.

Implementing it for my own sake is fine, and I have a prototype working, but I guess my main question is whether the maintainers are interested in getting pull request on a feature like this. Looking through the history here I see several attempts and fixes to this issue, none of them having been accepted. There is even an open pull request above from afflux that has had no action since June.

So I want to explain my approach to see if it is of interest:
Do not give audible notification, but only on-screen, if there is less than 5 minutes since the last message in the chat in question. Simple, but so far it seems to work very well in my use case. I have also added a feature toggle for it under notification settings where it is disabled by default. I am skeptical to the feature toggle tough, especially due to the first comment in contibuting.md, stating that “the answer is not more options”, but I will leave that discussion to the people.

My proposal is to start small and simple and look at more advanced features when we can get a feel for it. I can also add that my implementation so far is android only.

frikksol:

but I guess my main question is whether the maintainers are interested in getting pull request

Most likely not, if you are developing for one platform only.

Anyway, my prediction should not discourage you from implementing and submitting a pull request yourself. Who knows, maybe they’ll merge it. Also, the less you change to more likely your chances are. They have to audit every commit.

But then, if your commit is so short another community member can port it to iOS.

frikksol:

Do not notify if there is less than 5 minutes since the last message

It feels like way too much time. What you also don’t want is to miss messages because they were auto-muted. I suggest 1 min could be more appropriate.

I think what WA does (or was it TG?) was the following. The first two or three messages came in unfiltered. If there were more messages than that in a very short period of time it would still deliver them on screen, but without sound. (Not sure if the screen did turn on for those messages). The reason for the first 2-3 messages (tones) is that you still get the “feeling” that you are receiving “a lot” notifications. But you aren’t bothered by it.

The reason why I think it’s more like 1 min instead of 5 min; I had situations were I would be re-notified after 5 minutes that there are still incoming messages. So, even if I forgot the nerving chat, I got reminded “oh right there was something”. And then it would show something like delivered 25 messages, 5 minutes ago.

I really liked the behaviour because it was a perfect balance between not being bombarding with messages and not being left out. Especially, that the muting does not kick in immediatelly! Also the muting should be limited to each conversation separately. Receiving 20 messages from 20 different chats (none within the same group) should also not trigger a mute.

Telegram has another feature that does belong to this topic: Slow Mode. Though its only available for groups and would require at least a group management / admins of some kind (groups v2?).

Summary:
Slow Mode limits how often someone can post in a group. The group admin can set a Timer, e.g., 1 Minute, and each person has to wait that amount of time before posting a message again. This does not affect other people. The time counts only from your own last message.
